steps.title: Domain-Locked Expertise
steps.narration: You've been a senior engineer for a while. You know your service inside out, can navigate your codebase with your eyes closed. But here's the uncomfortable truth: your expertise is domain-locked.

steps.title: Back to Square One
steps.narration: When you need to review a PR in an unfamiliar service, integrate with a legacy system, or evaluate an acquisition target's code‚Äîyou're back to square one. All that expertise doesn't transfer automatically.

steps.title: The Traditional Timeline
steps.narration: The traditional approach takes 2 to 4 weeks to get productive in a new codebase. Week one for setup and exploration, week two for breaking things, week three for understanding flows, week four for finally being productive.

steps.title: The Amplified Timeline
steps.narration: But what if you could compress that to hours? Hours one and two for AI architecture overview, three and four for entry points and flows, five and six for patterns and risks. Day two: making contributions.

steps.title: The Key Insight
steps.narration: AI doesn't replace your expertise‚Äîit lets you acquire expertise faster. You're still the judge, the decision-maker, the one who knows what matters. AI is your research assistant, not your replacement.

steps.title: Facing a New Codebase
steps.narration: You're dropped into an unfamiliar codebase. Thousands of files, unknown patterns, undocumented decisions. Instead of manually reading everything, let AI do the initial reconnaissance.

steps.title: AI Analysis
steps.narration: Feed the codebase to AI and ask for structure, not details. Architecture summary, entry points, core data models, repeated patterns, areas of complexity, external integrations. Understand the shape before the substance.

steps.title: What AI Produces
steps.narration: AI gives you an architecture summary, maps the entry points, identifies patterns, and flags risk areas. All in about two hours of conversation instead of weeks of manual exploration.

steps.title: Senior Verification
steps.narration: Now YOU apply your judgment. Verify AI's claims against actual code‚ÄîAI makes mistakes. You know what matters for YOUR situation. Decide what to trust, what to investigate deeper, what to skip.

steps.title: Productive in Hours
steps.narration: Deep dive only where needed based on AI's map. By day two, you're making meaningful contributions. What took weeks now takes hours. Your expertise transfers across codebases.

steps.title: A Repeatable Process
steps.narration: This isn't magic‚Äîit's a repeatable 6-step protocol for mastering any codebase quickly. Each step builds on the previous, creating a systematic approach to rapid acquisition.

steps.title: Initial Reconnaissance
steps.narration: Step one: Feed AI the codebase and ask for structure, not details. Understand the shape before the substance. What are the major components? How do they relate?

steps.title: Entry Point Mapping
steps.narration: Step two: Where does execution start? API routes, CLI commands, job schedulers. These are your map's landmarks‚Äîthe places where external requests enter the system.

steps.title: Data Model Analysis
steps.narration: Step three: What are the nouns? Database schemas, domain objects, API types. Understanding data means understanding the system. Data shapes behavior.

steps.title: Pattern Recognition
steps.narration: Step four: How do they do things? Naming conventions, error handling, testing approaches. Learn the local dialect so your code fits in and follows established conventions.

steps.title: Risk Assessment
steps.narration: Step five: Where are the landmines? Complex areas, tech debt, missing tests, security concerns. Know what to avoid touching until you understand it deeply.

steps.title: Documentation Generation
steps.narration: Step six: What's missing? Have AI draft docs you wish existed‚Äîarchitecture diagrams, API documentation, onboarding guides. Then verify, refine, and contribute back.

steps.title: Codebase Mastery
steps.narration: Follow the protocol and you go from stranger to contributor in a day or two. This isn't about shortcuts‚Äîit's about systematic, AI-augmented learning that scales across any codebase.

questions.question: What is the 'senior plateau' problem?
options: Expertise is domain-locked and doesn't transfer to new codebases
questions.explanation: The senior plateau is when your deep expertise in your own codebase doesn't automatically transfer. In unfamiliar code, even seniors start from scratch‚Äîtraditionally taking 2-4 weeks to get productive.

questions.question: How long does the traditional approach take to get productive in a new codebase?
questions.explanation: Traditional codebase onboarding takes 2-4 weeks: setup and exploration, breaking things, understanding flows, and finally being productive. The amplified approach compresses this to hours.

questions.question: What's the key insight about AI-augmented learning?
options: AI replaces the need to understand code
AI helps you acquire expertise faster‚Äîyou still provide judgment
AI only works for simple codebases
questions.explanation: AI doesn't replace your expertise‚Äîit accelerates acquisition. You're still the judge who decides what's important, verifies AI's claims, and applies your experience. AI is your research assistant.

questions.question: What should you ask AI for when analyzing a new codebase?
questions.explanation: Ask AI for high-level structure: architecture summary, entry points, data models, patterns, complexity areas, and external integrations. Understand the shape before diving into details.

questions.question: What's YOUR job after AI provides its analysis?
options: Accept everything AI says as truth
Verify AI's claims, apply context, and use judgment
Ignore it and read the code manually
Forward it to your team without review
questions.explanation: AI makes mistakes! Your job is to verify claims against actual code, apply context (you know what matters for YOUR situation), and use judgment on what to trust, investigate, or skip.

questions.question: Why is senior verification critical?
options: AI lacks context about your specific situation and can make mistakes
questions.explanation: AI can hallucinate, miss context, and make errors. You bring domain knowledge, understanding of your specific goals, and experience to judge what's accurate and relevant.

questions.question: What's the first step in the Rapid Acquisition Protocol?
options: Initial reconnaissance‚Äîask AI for structure, not details
questions.explanation: Step 1 is Initial Reconnaissance: Feed AI the codebase and ask for high-level structure. Understand the shape before the substance‚Äîmajor components and how they relate.

questions.question: Why is 'Entry Point Mapping' important?
options: Entry points are where execution starts‚Äîyour map's landmarks
questions.explanation: Entry points (API routes, CLI commands, job schedulers) are where external requests enter the system. They're landmarks that help you navigate and trace how data flows through the codebase.

questions.question: What's the purpose of step 6‚ÄîDocumentation Generation?
options: To draft missing docs (architecture, APIs, guides), then verify and refine
Documentation isn't part of the protocol
questions.explanation: Step 6 is about creating docs you wish existed. Have AI draft architecture diagrams, API docs, onboarding guides‚Äîthen verify, refine, and contribute back. You improve the codebase for others.
